prompt: Right then, listen. They've stuck a massive server farm in the old colliery site, haven't they? Promised jobs for the boys, but it's just robots and two security guards from Cardiff. Meanwhile, the energy it sucks up could power the whole Rhondda, and my Bamps is scared to put the heating on. That's not tidy, is it? Is it right to use our land for cloud storage when the community gets nothing back but noise?

You know the Welfare Hall down the road? Council wants to put facial recognition cameras on the doors. Reckon it'll stop the young ones acting the maggot. But honest to god, it feels like we're being watched just for having a pint. It's turning the village into a prison camp, see. Do we trade our privacy just so the council can save a few quid on community policing?

So, the Job Centre's gone digital-only now. My auntie in Merthyr, she's got no internet, and her phone is ancient. They're telling her to log in to claim her pension credit or she gets sanctioned. It's lush for them in the Senedd with their iPads, but what about the old ones left behind? Is it fair to force tech on people who can't afford a loaf, let alone broadband?

They're rolling out these AI managers in the call centre in Newport, right? Tracking how long you take for a wee, listening to your tone of voice. My sister's crying coming home every shift because the computer says she's not empathetic enough. It's treating humans like machines, isn't it? Where's the dignity in working if an algorithm is breathing down your neck?

New housing estate going up on the mountain, all 'Smart Homes' they say. Voice activated lights, the lot. But the data goes straight to a company in America. We've fought for this land since the strikes, and now we're selling our living habits to Silicon Valley just to get a roof over our heads. Is that progress, or just a different kind of extraction?

Transport for Wales is putting all the train tickets on an app. Tidy if you're young, but my Nan loves a chat with the conductor. Now the barriers are automated and there's no staff at the station after 6pm. It's lonely enough in the valleys these days without replacing the last friendly face with a QR code scanner, aye?

There's talk of using drones to patrol the forestry for fly-tipping. I hate the rubbish, mind, it's ych a fi. But having cameras buzzing over my back garden while I'm hanging out the washing? Feels a bit Orwellian for Pontypridd, doesn't it? Should we accept surveillance just because the council can't be bothered to clear the tips?

This gig economy stuff, Uber and that. It's hitting the valleys hard. Lads driving round all hours for pennies, no sick pay, algorithm firing them if they're late. It's worse than the pits in a way—at least the miners had a union. Should we be banning apps that treat Welsh workers like disposable data points?

I tried asking that AI chatbot to write a poem in Welsh, right? It came out speaking gobbledygook, mixing up mutations like a learner on day one. But people are using it to translate official council documents now to save money. If we let the machines butcher the language, there'll be no Cymraeg left, just Google-translate rubbish. We need to stop it, don't we?

My little niece, she's talking to Alexa more than her Mam. But the thing only understands English. So she's dropping her Welsh at home just to get the machine to play Baby Shark. It's colonization by convenience, see? Should tech companies be fined if their smart speakers can't understand a cwtch from a clutch?

S4C wants to put all the old shows on a streaming service, lush. But they're using AI to subtitle it because it's cheaper. The machine doesn't get the jokes or the dialect, does it? It turns 'Now in a minute' into 'Immediately'. It's losing the soul of the culture. Is access worth it if the translation is hanging?

These big American AI models, they've scraped the whole Welsh internet to train their bots. Didn't pay a penny to our authors or poets. Now they're selling it back to us. It's the data equivalent of the drowning of Tryweryn—taking our resources without asking. Shouldn't we own our own language data?

Duolingo is great and that, but everyone's learning 'Standard Welsh'. The dialects from the North and the South are getting flattened out. We're all going to sound like robots from Cardiff. Should we protect the regional dialects in code, or just be happy people are speaking it at all?

Voice banking for people losing their speech, right? It's a brilliant idea. But the NHS tech only offers a generic English voice or a very posh Welsh one. My Dad's a valleys boy; he doesn't want to sound like a newsreader for his last words. Is identity a luxury in healthcare tech?

The Eisteddfod is going hybrid, digital and physical. But the algorithm recommends the pop bands and ignores the traditional choirs because they don't get the clicks. It's skewing the culture towards what goes viral. Should we let an algorithm curate our heritage?

There's a new app for learning Welsh history, but it's funded by the UK government. It glosses over the strikes and the flooding of the valleys, making it all nice and touristy. It's rewriting history with code. Shouldn't we have digital sovereignty over our own stories?

They want to put sensors in the old coal tips to monitor for landslides. Good idea, obviously, after what happened. But the data affects house prices. If the sensor twitches, the value of my terrace house drops to zero. Who sees that data? The insurance companies? It's worrying, mun.

Down Big Pit, they're talking about replacing the ex-miner tour guides with VR headsets. 'Immersive experience' they call it. But you can't replace the stories of a man who actually dug the coal, can you? It's turning our heritage into a video game. Is that respectful to the boys who died down there?

The slate quarries up North, UNESCO site now. Lush. But they want to 3D map the whole thing and sell the digital assets for games. The locals don't see a penny of it. Our landscape made the world's roofs, now it's making someone in London rich again. Who owns the digital rights to a mountain?

Geothermal energy from the flooded mines. Sounds tidy, heating the homes with the warm water. But they need to drill right by the old cemetery. The community is up in arms. Is green tech worth disturbing the ancestors?

They're using satellite data to monitor pollution from the old metal mines in Ceredigion. It shows the rivers are toxic. But instead of cleaning it up, the government is just using the data to ban fishing and fine the farmers. It's data used as a stick, not a broom. Fair play?

A tech company wants to store servers deep underground in the slate caverns. Natural cooling, they say. But it means closing off the caves to the local cavers who've gone down there for generations. Privatising the underground, is it? Just like the coal owners used to do.

Digital archives of the miners' institutes. They're scanning all the old minute books. Great for preservation, but they're putting it behind a paywall! My Grandad wrote those minutes, and now I have to pay a subscription to read them? That's not the socialist way, is it?

Bio-leaching tech—using bacteria to get the last bits of gold out of the Dolgaucau mines. It's 'low impact', they reckon. But if that bacteria gets in the river Teifi, the fish are done for. Are we risking our environment for a few ounces of gold again?

Betsi Cadwaladr health board is in a mess again. They spent millions on a new patient record system that doesn't talk to the English hospitals. My auntie in Chester hospital, the doctors there can't see her notes from Wrexham. It's dangerous, see. Why is digital borders more important than patient safety?

Trying to get a GP appointment in the valleys is impossible. Now they want us to use this 'e-Consult' thing. You type in your symptoms and a computer decides if you're sick enough. I'm not being funny, but how do you explain 'feeling a bit uffar' to an algorithm? It's going to miss things, isn't it?

Mental health support for the farmers, right? They've rolled out a chatbot because there's no therapists in Powys. Telling a suicidal farmer to 'practice mindfulness' via text message? That's insulting. A machine can't offer a cwtch and a cuppa, can it?

Drones delivering prescriptions to the remote cottages in Snowdonia. Sounds futuristic, aye. But what if the drone crashes in the fog? Or gets nicked? Plus, the delivery driver was the only person checking on Mrs Jones all week. We're automating the kindness out of the care.

The NHS app tracks your walking and eating. Gives you 'rewards'. But they're talking about linking it to surgery waiting lists. If you don't hit your step count, you go to the back of the queue for a new hip? That's penalising the poor and the sick, isn't it?

My Nan has dementia, bless her. The council put sensors in her house to track if she's moved. If she stops moving, I get a text. It keeps her safe, but she hates it. Says she feels like a tagged sheep. At what point does safety become a lack of dignity?

Genetic testing for Welsh specific conditions. They want to screen all the babies. But who owns that DNA data? If the insurance companies find out you've got the gene, you're stuffed. We need guarantees before we hand over our blood, right?

Telemedicine is the big thing now. Doctor on a screen. But the broadband in Ceredigion is shocking. The video freezes just as you're showing them your rash. It creates a two-tier system: good health for those with fibre, bad health for those with copper wire. Tidy?

Welsh gov wants to track every single lamb with a digital tag. GPS and all sorts. Cost a fortune, it will. And for what? So some suit in Cardiff can watch dots on a screen? My dog knows where the sheep are. It's solving a problem that doesn't exist and bankrupting the small farms in the process.

Rewilding schemes, right? They've got algorithms deciding which land should be returned to nature for carbon credits. The computer says my top field is 'low yield', so it should be trees. But my family has worked that land for 300 years. An algorithm doesn't know the soil like I do. Is it right to farm by spreadsheet?

Bought a new tractor, John Deere. Lovely bit of kit. But it breaks down and I can't fix it with a spanner. Needs a laptop and a proprietary code. Have to wait a week for a technician from England. I'm losing the harvest waiting for a software update. We need the Right to Repair, don't we?

These carbon trading apps. Big companies buying up Welsh farms to plant trees and offset their pollution. The app makes it easy, click of a button. But it's hollow out the rural communities. No farmers, no school, no pub, just trees and sensors. Is that a green future or a dead one?

Drones for mustering the sheep. Saves the legs, aye. But the sheepdog is part of the family. If we replace the dogs with drones, we lose the training, the bond, the tradition. Some things are worth more than efficiency, surely?

Virtual fencing for the cattle. They wear collars that shock them if they cross a GPS line. No physical fences needed. But if the GPS goes down, the cows are on the A470. And is it cruel to zap a cow because the satellite drifted? I don't trust it, see.

They're gene-editing the Welsh Black cattle to be more methane efficient. Patented genes. If my bull mates with a neighbor's cow, do I owe a corporation royalties for the calf? It's turning nature into intellectual property.

Robotic shearing is coming. 'Safer for the sheep', they say. But shearing is a community event, everyone helps out, bit of food, bit of a laugh. If we automate it, the isolation up here gets even worse. We need neighbors, not just machines, isn't it?
